text: Taiwan is home to TSMC, the world's leading chip manufacturer, producing over 50% of the world's semiconductors and 90% of advanced chips.
Fengjia Night Market in Taichung is one of Taiwan's largest night markets, attracting thousands of visitors daily with its diverse food options.
Taiwan has over 100 peaks above 3,000 meters, including Yushan (Jade Mountain), which is the highest peak in Northeast Asia at 3,952 meters.
Taiwan was the first country in Asia to legalize same-sex marriage (2019), marking a historic moment for LGBTQ+ rights.
Bubble tea was invented in Taiwan in the 1980s, with Chun Shui Tang in Taichung being one of the first shops to popularize the drink.
EVA Air, Taiwan's major airline, has operated Hello Kitty-themed aircraft and airport lounges, showcasing Taiwan's embrace of kawaii culture.
The Tropic of Cancer runs through Taiwan, giving it a unique climate that supports both tropical and temperate species.
During Ghost Month (the seventh lunar month), Taiwanese people perform various rituals and make offerings to honor their ancestors.
Taroko Gorge is a spectacular marble canyon in Taiwan, featuring stunning cliffs, waterfalls, and the famous Eternal Spring Shrine.
7-Eleven stores in Taiwan offer various services, including bill payments, package delivery, and ticket purchases, making them essential to daily life.
Taiwan was under Japanese rule for 50 years (1895–1945), leaving lasting cultural influences in architecture and cuisine.
Pineapple cakes are a beloved Taiwanese pastry, originally made with winter melon. The word for pineapple (旺來 ong-lai) sounds like “prosperity comes”.
Taiwan's High Speed Rail system connects major cities at speeds up to 300 km/h, making it one of Asia's most efficient transportation networks.
Taiwan has thousands of temples, many dedicated to various deities and serving as important community centers.
Betel nut chewing is a cultural phenomenon in some regions, with distinctive 'betel nut beauties' selling the nuts at roadside stands.
Taiwan's National Palace Museum houses one of the world's largest collections of Chinese artifacts.
Taiwan is a major producer of computer components, including motherboards.
Taiwan has numerous hot springs, especially in Beitou and Wulai, making it a popular destination for hot spring tourism.
Taiwan has one of the highest densities of convenience stores in the world — with over 10,000 stores nationwide, there's almost one on every corner.
The Formosan black bear is Taiwan's largest land animal and a symbol of the island's unique wildlife.
The Dutch established their first settlement in Taiwan in 1624, building Fort Zeelandia in Tainan.
The Spanish briefly colonized northern Taiwan from 1626 to 1642, establishing Fort San Salvador in Keelung.
The Dutch introduced Christianity to Taiwan in the 17th century, building Protestant churches and introducing new farming methods.
The Indigenous Peoples of Taiwan speak Austronesian languages, related to those in Hawaii, New Zealand, and the Philippines.
The Amis tribe's harvest festival (Ilisin) is one of Taiwan's most important indigenous celebrations.
The Bunun people are known for their unique 'eight-part harmony' singing style, recognized as an important cultural heritage.
During Ghost Month, Taiwanese people avoid swimming, whistling at night, and hanging clothes outside after dark.
Taiwan's Spring Scream Festival, held annually in Kenting, is one of the country's oldest and most famous music festivals.
The Golden Horse Awards, established in 1962, are among the most prestigious Chinese-language film awards.
Taipei 101 features a 660-ton tuned mass damper that helps it withstand typhoons and earthquakes.
In Chinese culture, the number 4 is considered unlucky because it sounds similar to the word for 'death'.
Taiwan has one of the highest densities of convenience stores in the world, with one store per 1,703 people.
Taiwan's garbage trucks play classical music — like Beethoven or Für Elise — to alert residents it's time to bring out the trash.

Xiaoliuqiu (小琉球) is one of the few places in the world where you can snorkel with sea turtles year-round. The island has a high population of green sea turtles, and they often swim just a few meters from the shore!
Sweet potato leaves are a beloved everyday veggie in Taiwan — rich in nutrients and often stir-fried with garlic or served in soup.
Taiwan experiences over 1,000 earthquakes a year, most of them minor — but major quakes like the 921 Earthquake in 1999 have left a lasting impact.
Taipei has one of the highest scooter densities in the world — with over 14 million registered scooters across Taiwan!
Taiwan has a temple that honors a loyal black dog — the Shiba Wang Gong Temple in New Taipei is dedicated to a pup remembered for his bravery.
Taiwan has active volcanoes — mostly in the north near Yangmingshan, where geothermal activity powers hot springs and fumaroles.
Over 70% of Taiwan is covered by mountains — with 268 peaks taller than 3,000 meters, it has the highest mountain density in the world.
Taipei holds the Guinness World Record for the longest rainbow ever recorded — it lasted 8 hours and 58 minutes on Nov 30, 2017.
The Yanshui Beehive Fireworks Festival is one of the world’s most dangerous — people wear helmets while fireworks shoot at the crowd!
Despite the name, Mongolian barbecue was invented in Taiwan in the 1950s by comedian Wu Zhaonan.
The world’s first cat café opened in Taipei in 1998 — starting a global trend of cozy cafés filled with friendly cats.
Taiwanese students have some of the longest school days in the world, averaging 9 to 10 hours per day.
Portuguese sailors called Taiwan ‘Ilha Formosa’ — meaning ‘Beautiful Island’ — for its stunning coastline and lush peaks.
Taiwan’s Beitou hot spring culture was developed during Japanese rule — complete with public baths and onsens still in use today.
The Taiwanese word for lunchbox, 'biandang' (便當), comes from the Japanese word 'bentō' — a legacy of Japanese rule.
Taiwan’s railway system was originally developed by the Japanese — many train stations still use Japanese architectural designs.
The Alishan Forest Railway was built by the Japanese in 1912 to transport timber — today, it's a scenic route famous for mountain views and sunrises.
In Taiwan, breakfast is a daily ritual — from soy milk & egg crepes to radish cake & fan tuan, local breakfast shops open before sunrise and are often more loved than Starbucks.
Taiwan has over 20,000 bubble tea shops — more than there are convenience stores. Some intersections have 3 boba shops side-by-side. That’s how much people love it.

Taiwan is the only place that still uses Zhuyin Fuhao (注音符號) — a phonetic system taught in schools to help kids learn Mandarin. Unlike in China, pinyin isn’t used in daily life here — Zhuyin is how we read, type, and pronounce.
